But everyone else seemed to have their life together – the young professionals typing away on their laptops, the couples laughing over steaming cups of coffee. I thought back to the countless hours I'd spent perfecting my resume, tailoring it to each job application. Hadn't I done everything right? But as I sat there, nursing my coffee, I couldn't shake off the feeling of inadequacy. What was wrong with me? Why couldn't I land a job like everyone else? The questions swirled in my head, taunting me with their silence. And when the tears finally came, I let them flow freely, mourning the loss of my dreams, one rejected application at a time.

In the midst of my despair, I spotted a flyer on the bulletin board – a local art studio offering free classes for underprivileged youth. A spark of hope flickered to life within me. Tomorrow would be better, I told myself. Tomorrow would bring change.

I've been trying online dating for what feels like an eternity – five years, to be exact. And let me tell you, it's been a complete waste of time. Every single profile I've swiped through has been a disaster waiting to happen. Guys who claim to be outdoorsy adventurers turn out to be couch potatoes, women who say they love hiking are actually stuck at home binge-watching Netflix.

It's not just the superficial stuff either; the conversations always seem forced and shallow. People can't even be bothered to ask real questions about themselves, let alone listen actively to my responses. It's like they're all just going through the motions, pretending to be interested in getting to know me when really they're just looking for a quick hook-up.

And don't even get me started on the ghosting. I swear, half the guys I've met have vanished into thin air without so much as a "hey, thanks for the chat." It's like they're allergic to commitment or something.

Needless to say, I'm done with online dating. Period. I'll stick to meeting people through mutual friends or at social events, where at least there's some semblance of genuine connection. Online dating? Forget about it. It's a lost cause.
